text.p: Following are the main stories in Croatian newspapers on Wednesday. Reuters has not verified them and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- Central bank to announce the introduction of a 10 kuna coin.
- Head of Croatian government's missing persons' commission Ivan Grujic says after talks with the members of the Yugoslav commission Croatia is still searching for some 2,300 people.

- Croatia signs fresh agreement on road reconstruction worth 250 million kuna with the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development as part of the "Betterment" programme under which four roads have already been reconstructed.

- The president of the city assembly Zlatko Canjuga says prior to Wednesday's electing of the assembly's new members that talks are under way with the HSLS members on their taking part in the establishment of the city authorities.
- Tudjman wins the elections in 111 out of 122 Croatian cities, according to HDZ's election headquarters.

- Croatia to start building two hydro-electric power plants. Once built, they will produce one fourth of the energy currently produced by the Krsko nuclear power plant. The start of construciton works for the Podsused hydro-electric plant is scheduled for 1999 and for the Drenje one for 2000 and is expected to last four years.
- Yugoslav delegation hands over to Croatia documents on a number of people killed in the Vukovar area in 1991.
- Croatian manufacturers of agricultural machinery boost their output: 507 tractors produced in the first two months this year, compared to 607 in all of 1996.
- The government is interested in attracting serious foreign investors with fresh cash to help tourism, says Marijan Bulat, director of the Croatian Tourist Board.
- Share of grey economy estimated at roughly 17-33 percent between 1990 and 1996, trade is seen as a paradise for tax evaders.
- Almost nine billion kuna in intercompany debts should be put on a secondary market, which would determine how much they are really worth and reduce them, says economist Vlado Leko.
- Stock market after election: Bears are not exhausted yet

- Not all Italian tourists who planned to spend their holidays on the Croatian coast will be able to do so. Most of the hotels are booked for the dates Italian tour operators had in mind. Some 37 Croatian hotels on the coast have already sent the 'stop booking' message to 45 Italian tour operators.
- A record 330 tonnes of crude is pumped daily from the Deletovci oil fields in Eastern Slavonia, some 86 tonnes more than planned. -- Zagreb Newsroom, 385-1-4557075
